articles.headline: Federal Review Finds Rules to Live Without
articles.snippet: The White House is trying to end what President Obama refers to as “just plain dumb” federal regulations, but not everyone is satisfied with the effort.
articles.abstract: The White House is trying to end what President Obama refers to as “just plain dumb” federal regulations, but not everyone is satisfied with the effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Thursday that it would rewrite hundreds of regulations to save businesses and consumers hundreds of millions of dollars a year, the first fruits of a review process announced in January.

articles.headline: China’s Interest in Farmland Makes Brazil Uneasy
articles.snippet: Even as Brazil, Argentina and other nations move to impose limits on farmland purchases by foreigners, the Chinese are seeking to more directly control production themselves.
articles.abstract: Even as Brazil, Argentina and other nations move to impose limits on farmland purchases by foreigners, the Chinese are seeking to more directly control production themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: URUAÇU, Brazil — When the Chinese came looking for more soybeans here last year, they inquired about buying land — lots of it.

articles.headline: Tests Reveal Mislabeling of Fish
articles.snippet: Recent technology that identifies varieties of fish by their gene sequences has shown that 20 to 25 percent of seafood products are being mislabeled.
articles.abstract: Recent technology that identifies varieties of fish by their gene sequences has shown that 20 to 25 percent of seafood products are being mislabeled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scientists aiming their gene sequencers at commercial seafood are discovering rampant labeling fraud in supermarket coolers and restaurant tables: cheap fish is often substituted for expensive fillets, and overfished species are passed off as fish whose numbers are plentiful.

articles.headline: Sony Chief Still in Search of a Turnaround
articles.snippet: Howard Stringer’s efforts at Sony have been stymied by the effects of the March 11 earthquake and tsunami, a hacker attack on the PlayStation network and other troubles.
articles.abstract: Howard Stringer’s efforts at Sony have been stymied by the effects of the March 11 earthquake and tsunami, a hacker attack on the PlayStation network and other troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In Sony’s 1993 comedy “Groundhog Day,” Bill Murray finds himself reliving the same dreary course of events, day after day.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: The Audacity of Chinese Frauds
articles.snippet: Fraud in Chinese stocks is not new, but several recent disasters are notable for the list of smart people who were fooled.
articles.abstract: Fraud in Chinese stocks is not new, but several recent disasters are notable for the list of smart people who were fooled.
articles.lead_paragraph: To pull off a fraud that humiliates the cream of the global financial elite, you need to have some friends. And where better to have them than at the local bank?

articles.headline: Mortgage Companies Settle Suits on Military Foreclosures
articles.snippet: Subsidiaries of Bank of America and Morgan Stanley will pay scores of service members at least $22 million for violating a law on foreclosures.
articles.abstract: Subsidiaries of Bank of America and Morgan Stanley will pay scores of service members at least $22 million for violating a law on foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two mortgage servicing companies have agreed to settle federal complaints that they wrongfully foreclosed on the homes of at least 178 military service members and to set aside a minimum of $22 million to compensate those victims.

articles.headline: When Children’s Scribbles Hide a Prison Drug
articles.snippet: A treatment for opiate addiction has become a favorite contraband among prisoners nationwide, and a constant test for prison officials.
articles.abstract: A treatment for opiate addiction has become a favorite contraband among prisoners nationwide, and a constant test for prison officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINDHAM, Me. — Mike Barrett, a corrections officer, ripped open an envelope in the mail room at the Maine Correctional Center here and eyed something suspicious: a Father’s Day card, sent a month early. He carefully felt the card and slit it open, looking for a substance that has made mail call here a different experience of late.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Katie Zezima

articles.headline: Aid Pledge by Group of 8 Seeks to Bolster Arab Democracy
articles.snippet: The world’s leading industrialized nations said they would help revive the economies of Egypt and Tunisia to help anchor stability in the region.
articles.abstract: The world’s leading industrialized nations said they would help revive the economies of Egypt and Tunisia to help anchor stability in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEAUVILLE, France — Leaders of the Group of 8 wealthiest industrialized nations pledged on Friday to send billions of dollars in aid to Egypt and Tunisia, hoping to reduce the threat that economic stagnation could undermine the transition to democracy.

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Scrambles to Limit Region’s Upheaval
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia is flexing its financial and diplomatic might in a bid to avert the overthrow of any more leaders in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia is flexing its financial and diplomatic might in a bid to avert the overthrow of any more leaders in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Saudi Arabia is flexing its financial and diplomatic might across the Middle East in a wide-ranging bid to contain the tide of change, shield other monarchies from popular discontent and avert the overthrow of any more leaders struggling to calm turbulent nations.
